unnormalised: The Indian stock market experienced a volatile trading session today, with the Sensex closing at 65,220.53, a marginal gain of 0.05%. Nifty 50 also saw muted movement, settling at 19,398.50. Initial trading hours witnessed significant buying interest, fueled by positive global cues and encouraging Q1 results from major corporations. However, profit booking in the afternoon session led to a pullback, erasing earlier gains.
normalised: The Indian stock market experienced a volatile trading session today, with the Sensex closing at sixty five thousand two hundred and twenty point fifty three, a marginal gain of zero point zero five percent. Nifty fifty also saw muted movement, settling at nineteen thousand three hundred and ninety eight point fifty. Initial trading hours witnessed significant buying interest, fueled by positive global cues and encouraging Q one results from major corporations. However, profit booking in the afternoon session led to a pullback, erasing earlier gains.

unnormalised: Sectoral performance was mixed. IT stocks continued their upward trajectory, with Infosys (INFY) and TCS (TCS) leading the gains. The banking sector remained under pressure due to concerns over rising NPAs. State Bank of India (SBI) shares declined by 1.2%.
normalised: Sectoral performance was mixed. I-T stocks continued their upward trajectory, with Infosys (I-N-F-Y) and T-C-S (T-C-S) leading the gains. The banking sector remained under pressure due to concerns over rising N-P-As. State Bank of India (S-B-I) shares declined by one point two percent.

unnormalised: Foreign Institutional Investors (FIIs) were net sellers, offloading shares worth Rs. 1,245.78 crore. Domestic Institutional Investors (DIIs), on the other hand, provided some support, with net purchases of Rs. 876.54 crore. Analysts attribute the FII selling to rising US bond yields and a stronger dollar.
normalised: Foreign Institutional Investors (F-I-Is) were net sellers, offloading shares worth rupee one thousand two hundred and forty five point seventy eight crore. Domestic Institutional Investors (D-I-Is), on the other hand, provided some support, with net purchases of rupee eight hundred and seventy six point fifty four crore. Analysts attribute the F-I-I selling to rising U-S bond yields and a stronger dollar.

unnormalised: Among individual stocks, Reliance Industries (RIL) witnessed a surge in trading volume following the announcement of its AGM date. The stock closed at Rs. 2,550, a gain of 0.8%. HDFC Bank (HDB) also saw buying interest after its Q1 results were released.
normalised: Among individual stocks, Reliance Industries (R-I-L) witnessed a surge in trading volume following the announcement of its A-G-M date. The stock closed at rupee two thousand five hundred and fifty, a gain of zero point eight percent. H-D-F-C Bank (H-D-B) also saw buying interest after its Q one results were released.

unnormalised: The IPO market remains active. The issue price of the latest IPO, "ABC Technologies", has been fixed at Rs. 450 per share. The IPO is scheduled to open on 28/08/2024. Market experts advise investors to carefully evaluate the company's fundamentals before investing in IPOs.
normalised: The I-P-O market remains active. The issue price of the latest I-P-O, "A-B-C Technologies", has been fixed at rupee four hundred and fifty per share. The I-P-O is scheduled to open on twenty eighth august two thousand and twenty four. Market experts advise investors to carefully evaluate the company's fundamentals before investing in I-P-Os.

unnormalised: The Indian Rupee (INR) depreciated slightly against the US dollar, closing at 83.20. The depreciation was attributed to increased demand for dollars from oil importers. The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) is closely monitoring the currency market.
normalised: The Indian Rupee (I-N-R) depreciated slightly against the U-S dollar, closing at eighty three point twenty. The depreciation was attributed to increased demand for dollars from oil importers. The Reserve Bank of India (R-B-I) is closely monitoring the currency market.

unnormalised: Going forward, market participants are anticipating the release of key macroeconomic data, including the CPI inflation numbers and the Index of Industrial Production (IIP). These data points are expected to provide further direction to the market. Investors are advised to remain cautious and adopt a stock-specific approach. Technical analysts suggest that Nifty has support around 19,200 and resistance near 19,500. The long-term outlook for the Indian stock market remains positive, driven by strong economic growth and improving corporate earnings.
normalised: Going forward, market participants are anticipating the release of key macroeconomic data, including the C-P-I inflation numbers and the Index of Industrial Production (I-I-P). These data points are expected to provide further direction to the market. Investors are advised to remain cautious and adopt a stock-specific approach. Technical analysts suggest that Nifty has support around nineteen thousand two hundred and resistance near nineteen thousand five hundred. The long-term outlook for the Indian stock market remains positive, driven by strong economic growth and improving corporate earnings.
